exercise.title: Network Cascades from Singleton Seed Sets

idx.h: Network Cascades from Singleton Seed Sets

statement.p:
Consider this network with linear threshold q=1/3. Start a cascade by picking any single vertex to be the initial adopter. Does it spread to the entire network? What about the other vertices? Which ones lead to complete cascades?
For q=1/3, every singleton induces a complete cascade.

exercise.title: Network Cascades that are Not Complete

idx.h: Network Cascades that are Not Complete

statement.p:
Continue using threshold q=1/2 for the network above. Find all of the initial adopter sets of size 2 that do not lead to complete cascades. Can you describe the network obstruction that prevented the cascade from expanding across the entire network?
The 2-sets that do not spark complete cascades are: \{1,5\} and \{1,7\} and \{5,7\} and \{1,3\}. For the first three sets, the cascade cannot jump out of the triangle T=\{1,5,7\}. The vertices that border set T have more neighbors in \overline{A} than in A, so they never adopt. Starting with set \{1,3\}, there is no cascade.

Let {G=(V,E)} be a network with threshold q \in [0,1]. Let {S_0} be the initial set of innovators. Recall that a set S is cohesive when
p(S) = \min_{i \in S} \frac{ | N(i) \cap S| }{|N(i)|} > 1-q
where N(i) is the set of neighbors of i.
Suppose that the initial adopter set {S_0} does not cause a complete cascade. Prove that there is a cohesive set {S \subset V \backslash S_0}.
Let T be the set of vertices that adopt behavior A during the cascade. Let S= \overline{T} be the vertices that never adopt the behavior. For every i \in S, we have
\frac{ | N(i) \cap S| }{|N(i)|} > 1-q.
(Otherwise, i would have adopted behavior A.) But this means that
p(S) = \min_{i \in S} \frac{ | N(i) \cap S| }{|N(i)|} > 1-q.
Therefore the set is cohesive.
Suppose that there is a cohesive set {S \subset V \backslash S_0}. Prove that initial adopter set {S_0} does not cause a complete cascade.
We claim that no vertex in S ever adopts behavior A. Assume for the sake of contradiction that i \in S is the first vertex in S to adopt the innovation A. But even if every vertex outside of S has adopted behavior A, we still have
\frac{ | N(i) \cap S| }{|N(i)|} > 1-q,
and none of the vertices in S have adopted the innovation. So i does not adopt A, a contradiction. Therefore no vertex in S adopts the innovation.
